questions.text: The image below shows the insertion of transversus abdominis muscle. Identify the conjoint tendon: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

The structure marked C is the conjoint tendon.

 

The conjoint tendon is formed from the lower fibres of internal oblique and the lower part of the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis. It is attached to the pubic crest and extends to a variable extent along the pectineal line.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A- Thoracolumbar fascia - This fascia covers the deep muscles of the back and abdomen at the thoracic and lumbar regions.

 

Option B. B- Fibers of transverse abdominis

 

Option D. D- Inguinal ligament - A band running from the pubic tubercle to the anterior superior iliac spine, forming the lower border of the abdomen and serving as a landmark in hernia repairs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transversus Abdominis muscle

 

Origin: Internal surface of 7th -12th costal cartilages, thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, connective tissue deep to lateral third of inguinal ligament.

 

Insertion: Linea Alba with aponeurosis of internal oblique, pubic crest, and pecten pubis via the conjoint tendon.

questions.text: A child was brought with pedal edema and cheilosis. Further investigations revealed cardiomegaly. What is the vitamin deficiency associated with this clinical presentation?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine

 

The given clinical presentation with pedal edema and cardiomegaly is suggestive of wet beriberi, which is a consequence of thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Thiamine deficiency, also known as beriberi, is a more likely candidate. Thiamine deficiency can manifest as cardiac beriberi, leading to an enlarged heart (cardiomegaly), which aligns with the clinical findings. Thiamine deficiency can also cause peripheral edema, such as pedal edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Riboflavin deficiency can lead to cheilosis, which is consistent with one of the symptoms observed. However, it is not typically associated with pedal edema or cardiomegaly.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine deficiency is not commonly associated with pedal edema, cheilosis, or cardiomegaly.

 

Option D. Niacin (Vitamin B3): Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which includes symptoms like dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. It is not typically associated with cardiomegaly or pedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B1 deficiency disorders

choices.text: Parathyroid gland and hyperparathyroidism
Bone and Metabolic Bone Disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with proximal weakness, lethargy, low/depressed mood, and recurrent renal stones. Laboratory testing revealed a normal S. Calcium and increased PTH levels. What is the organ involved and the pathology? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid gland and hyperparathyroidism

 

The clinical presentation of proximal weakness, lethargy, low mood, and recurrent renal stones, combined with laboratory findings of normal serum calcium and increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, is indicative of primary hyperparathyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism is typically associated with hypercalcemia, but there is a variant known as normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism. In this condition, patients exhibit elevated PTH levels while maintaining normal serum calcium levels.

 

Key Features:

 

  • Proximal Weakness and Lethargy: Common symptoms of hyperparathyroidism due to muscle weakness and fatigue.
  • Low/Depressed Mood: Psychiatric manifestations are frequently seen in hyperparathyroidism.
  • Recurrent Renal Stones: Hyperparathyroidism leads to increased calcium excretion, resulting in kidney stones.
  • Normal Serum Calcium and Increased PTH: In normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism, PTH levels are elevated, but serum calcium levels remain within the normal range.

 

This condition is a diagnosis of exclusion, meaning other causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism (e.g., vitamin D deficiency, chronic kidney disease) must be ruled out first. Given the absence of clinical findings suggesting vitamin deficiency, osteomalacia, or chronic kidney disease in this case, normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroid and Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism does not present with the combination of symptoms and laboratory findings described.

 

Option C. Adrenal and Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytoma typically presents with episodic hypertension, headaches, and palpitations, not the symptoms and lab findings described.

 

Option D. Bone and Metabolic Bone Disease: While metabolic bone diseases can cause weakness and other symptoms, they do not typically present with elevated PTH and normal calcium as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism presents with normal serum calcium and elevated PTH levels and is associated with symptoms like proximal weakness, lethargy, low mood, and recurrent renal stones. It is a diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out other causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: Identify the structure passing through the foramen marked 2? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Abducens nerve

 

The foramen marked as 2 in the given image is the superior orbital fissure and the abducens nerve passes through it.

 

Superior ophthalmic fissure is divided into 3 parts by annulus of zinn, parts of fissure and structures passing via each part are listed below:

  1. Superior -lateral part - Lacrimal nerve, frontal nerve, trochlear nerve, superior opthalmic vein, lacrimal artery, meningeal branch of lacrimal artery. (Lacrimal nerve, frontal nerve and trochlear nerve are the branches of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve.
  2. Middle/ Intermediate part - Nasocillary nerve (branch of ophthalmic division of trigeminal), occulomotor nerve (CN 3), abducens nerve (CN - 6) 
  3. Infero - medial part - Inferior opthalmic vein.


Note - Opthalmic vein passes via superior orbital fissure and not artery. Opthalmic artery passes via optic canal.
 

Brief summary about important structures passing via superior ophthalmic fissure is given below
 

Abducens Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI): The abducens nerve is responsible for controlling the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is essential for eye abduction (outward movement). Damage to the abducens nerve can result in difficulty moving the affected eye outward, leading to diplopia (double vision) when looking toward the affected side.

 

Ophthalmic Division of Trigeminal Nerve (Cranial Nerve V1): The ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from the upper face, including the forehead, scalp, and anterior part of the scalp. It also provides sensory innervation to the cornea, conjunctiva, and other structures within the orbit.

 

Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV): The trochlear nerve controls the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which is responsible for rotating the eye downward and laterally. Damage to the trochlear nerve can lead to difficulty moving the affected eye downward and inward, causing vertical diplopia.

 

Superior ophthalmic vein

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spinal Accessory Nerve: This nerve does not pass through the superior orbital fissure. It primarily traverses the jugular foramen and is involved in motor functions, particularly in controlling the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

Option C. Ophthalmic Artery: Although the ophthalmic artery passes through the orbit, it is not transmitted through the foramen marked 2 but accompanies the optic nerve through the optic canal.

 

Option D. Middle Meningeal Artery: The middle meningeal artery enters the cranial cavity through the foramen spinosum, not the superior orbital fissure.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: FAD status in body is determined by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione reductase

 

This is the correct answer. Glutathione reductase is an enzyme that contains FAD as a prosthetic group and plays a significant role in the reduction of glutathione disulfide (GSSG) to glutathione (GSH). The activity of glutathione reductase, which depends on the availability of FAD, can be used to assess tissue riboflavin (FAD precursor) status. Therefore, measuring the activity of glutathione reductase with and without FAD is a method for assessing FAD status in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is not directly involved in determining FAD status. Thiamine plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism but doesn't directly influence the levels of FAD in the body.

 

Option C. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is an enzyme involved in the first step of glucose metabolism, but it is not responsible for determining FAD status.

 

Option D. Transketolase: Transketolase is marker enzyme for B1 deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FAD is the active form of Vitamin B2 and marker for the B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity as this enzyme require B2 as coenzyme. So, in case of FAD deficiency, glutathione reductase activity will be lowered without affecting the quantity of enzyme.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 534

questions.text: A patient recovered from hepatitis B infection. Which of the following curve represents antibodies seen 4 weeks post-recovery? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti HBs

 

After recovery from hepatitis B infection, the patient will have antibodies against the hepatitis B surface antigen (anti-HBS), indicating immunity. The key points related to hepatitis B infection and recovery include:

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Initially present during the acute phase of infection, indicating active infection. It will eventually drop and become negative upon recovery.

 

Anti-HBc (Hepatitis B core antibody): Initially, anti-HBc IgM is positive during the acute phase, which then transitions to anti-HBc IgG as the infection progresses. The total anti-HBc represents both IgM initially and IgG later on.

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen): Indicates active viral replication and high infectivity. It decreases as the virus is cleared.

 

Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): The protective antibody indicating recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection. This antibody appears after the disappearance of HBsAg and is a marker of immunity post-recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti HBc: Anti-HBc indicates past or current infection with hepatitis B. Initially, IgM anti-HBc is present during the acute infection, and later, IgG anti-HBc persists. However, it does not specifically indicate recovery and immunity.


Option C. HBeAg: HBeAg is a marker of active viral replication and high infectivity. It is present during the active infection phase and decreases as the infection resolves.


Option D. HBsAg: HBsAg indicates active hepatitis B infection. It is present during the acute phase of infection and disappears upon recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-HBs antibodies indicate recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection. This is the only protective antibody that signifies the patient has successfully recovered from the infection and has developed immunity.

questions.text: While working at a rural health sub-centre, you and a medical intern are analyzing annual infant registration metrics. The intern inquires about the expected annual infant registration rate when a health worker is actively on duty at the sub center. What is the best representation of this rate? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 150

 

Each year, a total of 150 infants should be enrolled at a sub-centre.

 

Annual infant population = Total population × % infants in population or expected birth rate

 

The infant population percentage, or the anticipated birth rate, ought to be derived from local data. In cases where a specific local percentage is not accessible, it is approximated at 3% of the overall population.

 

Total population in a sub centre = 5000.

 

Here, annual infant population = 5000 × 3/100 = 150

 

Total population catered by a Sub centre = 5000

 

Crude birth rate (CBR) India = 19 per 1000 Mid-year population (SRS 2016)

 

So, estimated number of births in a year = 19/1000 ×5000 = 95 births per year

 

  • Also, current Infant mortality rate (IMR) India = 28 per 1000 Live births
  • So, Expected number of infant deaths in a year in that population = 28/1000 × 95 = 2.7 deaths
  • So, total number of expected alive infants = 95 – 2.7 = 92 Infants approximately

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a rural health sub-centre, the expected annual infant registration rate effectively captures both the births and adjustments for infant mortality.
  • The number 150 serves as a practical target for ensuring all newborns are accounted for within the community health system.
  • This figure supports proactive health planning and resource allocation, emphasizing the importance of accurate and timely health data registration.

questions.text: A young child presented with nocturnal chest pain and a history of syncope has the ECG shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brugada syndrome

  

The ECG provided shows the characteristic pattern of Brugada syndrome, which includes:

 

  1. Pseudo-right bundle branch block pattern in leads V1 and V2.
  2. ST-segment elevation in the right precordial leads (V1-V2).
  3. Coving of the ST segment.
  4. T-wave inversion following the ST-segment elevation.

 

Brugada syndrome is a genetic disorder that predisposes individuals to ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, often occurring at rest or during sleep. It is more prevalent in young males and can present with symptoms such as nocturnal chest pain, syncope, or sudden cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial infarction: Typically presents with ST-segment elevation in contiguous leads but does not usually show the pseudo-right bundle branch block pattern seen in Brugada syndrome.

 

Option B. HOCM (Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy): Characterized by left ventricular hypertrophy and possible left atrial enlargement, often presenting with deep Q waves and signs of left ventricular hypertrophy on ECG, not the specific pattern seen here.

 

Option D. DCM (Dilated Cardiomyopathy): Shows global left ventricular dilation and systolic dysfunction, which can lead to low voltage QRS complexes, left bundle branch block, or non-specific ST-T changes but not the specific Brugada pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brugada syndrome should be suspected in patients, especially young males, with a history of syncope or nocturnal chest pain presenting with the characteristic ECG pattern of pseudo-right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevation in leads V1 and V2.

questions.text: The enzyme that is not used in cholesterol synthesis? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HMG CoA lyase

 

Initially, acetoacetyl CoA is formed by condensation of two molecules of acetyl-CoA by cytosolic thiolase which then enters the cholesterol synthesis pathway along with a molecule of acetyl-CoA.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiolase: Thiolase is involved in the initial steps of cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option B. HMG CoA Reductase: HMG CoA reductase is a key enzyme in the cholesterol synthesis pathway.

 

Option C. HMG CoA Synthase: HMG CoA Synthase: HMG CoA synthase is involved in Both cholesterol synthesis and ketone body synthesis by forming HMG-CoA.

 

Educational Objective :

 

HMG CoA lyase is not used in the cholesterol synthesis pathway; it is involved in ketogenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following neurons predominantly fire during forceful expiration?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ventral group of neurons

 

Ventral respiratory group of neurons, are located on each side of medulla found in the nucleus ambigus rostrally and the nucleus retroambigus caudally.

 

The function of this neuronal group differs from dorsal group by -

 

  1. The neurons of the ventral respiratory group remain almost totally inactive during normal quiet respiration.
  2. Does not participate in the basic rhythmical oscillation that controls respiration
  3. When the respiratory drive for increased pulmonary ventilation becomes greater than normal, respiratory signals spill over into the ventral respiratory neurons from the basic oscillating mechanism of the dorsal respiratory area
  4. Electrical stimulation of a few of the neurons in the ventral group causes inspiration, whereas stimulation of others causes expiration. Therefore, these neurons contribute to both inspiration and expiration. They are especially important in providing the powerful expiratory signals to the abdominal muscles during very heavy expiration. Thus, this area operates more or less as an overdrive mechanism when high levels of pulmonary ventilation are required, especially during heavy exercise.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dorsal group of neurons: Incorrect because the DRG is mainly active during quiet breathing and primarily controls inspiration.

 

Option C. Pneumotaxic center: Incorrect as the pneumotaxic center primarily modulates the switch between inhalation and exhalation to control the rate and pattern of breathing, rather than directly causing forceful expiration.

 

Option D. Chemoreceptors: Incorrect because chemoreceptors detect changes in the chemical composition of the blood (like CO2 and O2 levels) and influence the respiratory centers indirectly rather than actively firing during respiratory movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ventral Respiratory Group of neurons, particularly some subsets within this group, are actively involved in generating the neural signals required for forceful expiration, making them essential during increased respiratory demands such as during intense physical activity.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient weighing 60 kg is on mechanical ventilation for ARDS secondary to urosepsis. The respiratory parameters are as follows: tidal volume- 360 mL; frequency- 30 breaths/min; PEEP- 5 cm of H2O; and FiO2- 90%. The arterial blood gas findings are as follows: paO2- 50 mmHg; paCO2- 38 mmHg and pH- 7.38. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase PEEP

 

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) requires careful management of mechanical ventilation settings to optimize oxygenation while minimizing lung injury. The patient's current settings and blood gas findings suggest hypoxemia (paO2 of 50 mmHg) with an FiO2 of 90%. The goal in managing ARDS is to maintain adequate oxygenation (paO2 > 60 mmHg) while reducing the FiO2 to less than 60% to avoid oxygen toxicity.

 

Increasing PEEP is the best option to improve oxygenation. PEEP helps to keep alveoli open, improving gas exchange and oxygenation. By increasing PEEP, we can potentially increase the paO2 and eventually reduce the FiO2 to safer levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduce FiO2: Although reducing FiO2 is a long-term goal to prevent oxygen toxicity, it is not advisable to reduce it immediately because the patient is currently hypoxemic (paO2 of 50 mmHg).

 

Option B. Increase tidal volume: Not appropriate as it can increase the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury in ARDS patients. The current tidal volume is within the safe range (360 mL), which is appropriate for a 60 kg patient as it falls within the recommended range of 4-6 mL/kg for ARDS patients to prevent ventilator-induced lung injury.

 

Option C. Increase respiratory rate: Increasing the respiratory rate is not necessary in this situation as the paCO2 (38 mmHg) and pH (7.38) indicate normal ventilation and no significant respiratory acidosis (paCO2 is normal).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS management, if the patient remains hypoxemic despite a high FiO2, the next step is to increase the PEEP to improve oxygenation while maintaining lung-protective ventilation strategies.

questions.text: Identify the site which is responsible for relieving pain when pressure is applied to the painful area? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Periaqueductal gray

 

The analgesia system consists of three major components:

 

(1) The periaqueductal gray and periventricular areas of the mesencephalon and upper pons surround the aqueduct of Sylvius and portions of the third and fourth ventricles. Neurons from these areas send signals to  

 

(2) the raphe magnus nucleus, a thin midline nucleus located in the lower pons and upper medulla, and the nucleus reticularis paragigantocellularis, located laterally in the medulla. From these nuclei, second-order signals are transmitted down the dorsolateral columns in the spinal cord to

 

(3) a pain inhibitory complex located in the dorsal horns of the spinal cord. At this point, the analgesia signals can block the pain before it is relayed to the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corticospinal tract: Incorrect. This tract is involved in motor control and voluntary movements, not pain relief.

 

Option C. Medial lemniscus: Incorrect. This pathway carries sensory information related to touch, vibration, and proprioception, not pain relief.

 

Option D. Medial longitudinal fasciculus: Incorrect. This bundle of nerve fibers coordinates eye movements and helps maintain balance, not pain relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The periaqueductal gray (PAG) is a critical component of the analgesia system, responsible for relieving pain by sending inhibitory signals to block pain transmission in the spinal cord.

choices.text: To break AT bonds high Tm is required
To break GC bonds low Tm is required
To break AT bonds low Tm is required
AT bonds and GC bonds need the same TM

questions.text: Which of the following is true? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To break AT bonds low Tm is required

 

To break AT bonds low Tm is required: This statement is correct. AT bonds are held together by two hydrogen bonds, which are relatively weak compared to GC bonds. Therefore, lower temperatures (low Tm) are required to break AT bonds, causing the DNA to denature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To break AT bonds high Tm is required: This statement is incorrect. The melting temperature (Tm) of DNA is the temperature at which the double-stranded DNA molecule begins to denature or separate into single strands. AT bonds (adenine-thymine) are held together by two hydrogen bonds, which are weaker than the three hydrogen bonds holding GC bonds (guanine-cytosine) together. Therefore, lower temperatures (relatively low Tm) are required to break AT bonds.

 

Option B. To break GC bonds low Tm is required: This statement is incorrect. GC bonds have a higher Tm compared to AT bonds because they are held together by three hydrogen bonds, making them more stable. So, higher temperatures (relatively high Tm) are required to break GC bonds.

 

Option D. AT bonds and GC bonds need the same Tm: This statement is incorrect. As explained above, AT bonds and GC bonds have different Tm values due to the difference in the number of hydrogen bonds holding them together.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DNA, there are two hydrogen bonds between A and T and three hydrogen bonds between G and C. So, AT bonds will require a lower Tm (melting temperature) compared to GC bonds as less energy is required for breaking 2 bonds compared to three bonds.

questions.text: Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not sufficient to diagnose which of the following conditions? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid

 

FNAC is insufficient for diagnosing follicular carcinoma of the thyroid because this cancer is differentiated from follicular adenoma based on capsular invasion and vascular invasion, which FNAC cannot detect. Diagnosing follicular carcinoma requires histological examination to demonstrate cellular invasion of the capsule or vascular channels. Intraoperative frozen sections are also ineffective in definitively diagnosing follicular carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid: FNAC is typically adequate for diagnosing papillary carcinoma due to its distinct cytological features.

 

Option C. Breast carcinoma: FNAC is generally effective in diagnosing breast carcinoma as it can identify malignant cells.

 

Option D. Lung adenocarcinoma: FNAC can be used to diagnose lung adenocarcinoma, identifying characteristic cellular features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FNAC is not sufficient for diagnosing follicular carcinoma of the thyroid because it cannot detect capsular or vascular invasion, which is essential for differentiation from follicular adenoma.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient is diagnosed with osteosarcoma and is scheduled to undergo chemotherapy as part of his treatment. Methotrexate is included in his chemotherapy regimen. What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of his osteosarcoma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibitor of DHFR.

 

Methotrexate has different mechanisms for anticancer activity and for Rheumatoid Arthritis.

 

Mechanism in Osteosarcoma (As anticancer drug): Methotrexate acts as a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate interferes with the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, an essential cofactor for DNA synthesis. This leads to a decrease in DNA and RNA synthesis, thereby arresting the cell cycle and inhibiting the growth of rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells in osteosarcoma.

 

Mechanism in Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA): Methotrexate is used at much lower doses in Rheumatoid Arthritis. In this condition, the major mechanism involves the inhibition of an enzyme called AICAR transformylase, part of the purine synthesis pathway. When AICAR transformylase is inhibited, levels of AICAR (5-aminoimidazole-4-carboxamide ribonucleotide) accumulate in the cell. This leads to an inhibition of another enzyme called adenosine deaminase, which is responsible for the degradation of adenosine. As a result, adenosine levels increase within the cell and in the extracellular environment. Adenosine is known to have anti-inflammatory properties. When adenosine interacts with its receptors, it can lead to various effects such as inhibition of inflammatory cell function, vasodilation, and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine release. These actions contribute to the anti-inflammatory effects observed when methotrexate is used for treating RA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Analog of UMP: Methotrexate is not an analog of UMP (uridine monophosphate). It does not exert its effects through this mechanism.

 

Option C. Blocks purine synthesis: Methotrexate does not specifically block purine synthesis, although the inhibition of DHFR indirectly affects purine and pyrimidine synthesis.

 

Option D. Blocks pyrimidine synthesis: Similar to Option C, methotrexate does not specifically block pyrimidine synthesis but indirectly affects it through DHFR inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate's primary mechanism of action in treating osteosarcoma is as a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), which interferes with DNA synthesis and cell division in rapidly dividing cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major diagnostic criterion of neuromyelitis Optica? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Focal epilepsy

 

Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) spectrum disorder, also known as Devic's disease, is an autoimmune condition characterized by severe, recurrent episodes of optic neuritis and myelitis. The diagnostic criteria for NMO spectrum disorders include specific clinical syndromes.  

 

Focal epilepsy is not a diagnostic criterion for NMO. While seizures can occur in NMOSD due to brain lesions, focal epilepsy itself is not a major diagnostic feature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Area postrema syndrome  is major criteria. This is characterized by intractable nausea, vomiting, or hiccups, which is due to lesions in the area postrema of the brainstem.

 

Option B. Acute myelitis is major criteria. Inflammation of the spinal cord, usually longitudinally extensive (spanning three or more vertebral segments).

 

Option D. Optic neuritis is major criteria. This involves inflammation of the optic nerve, leading to vision loss or impairment, often affecting both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD)

 

Most Common Core Clinical criteria:

 

  1. Longitudinal extensive transverse myelitis (acute myelitis)
  2. Optic neuritis, often bilateral
  3. Area postrema syndrome

 

Less Common Clinical Criteria:

 

  1. Acute brainstem syndrome
  2. Acute diencephalic syndrome, which can manifest as symptomatic narcolepsy
  3. Symptomatic cerebral syndrome (symptomatic cerebral lesions)

 

Some patients with NMOSD may have anti-NMO IgG antibody positivity, also known as anti-aquaporin 4 antibody (AQP4-IgG).

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is not supplied by the structure marked by red arrow? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior oblique

 

The superior oblique muscle is not supplied by the oculomotor nerve, which is the structure highlighted in the figure. Superior oblique muscle is supplied by the trochlear nerve.

 

All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

 

  • ﻿﻿Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • ﻿﻿Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior rectus: This muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve, which is the structure indicated by the red arrow in the image. This muscle helps in elevating the eye.

 

Option C. Medial rectus: Also supplied by the oculomotor nerve, this muscle is responsible for adducting the eye towards the nose.

 

Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris (LPS): Innervated by the oculomotor nerve, the LPS is essential for elevating the upper eyelid, enabling the opening of the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling and ataxia. Which among the following could likely be a cause? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

 

This was an atypical question, which is important only if it is repeated in a subsequent exam.

 

The most likely cause in the following case is Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) - Diffuse Large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL) type.

 

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of NHL.

 

The median patient age is about 60 years, but DLBCL also occurs in young adults and children.

 

DLBCL commonly presents with enlarged lymph nodes or rapidly growing mass along with B symptoms, which include fever, night sweats, and weight loss. The B symptoms can be seen in 30% of the patients. Bone marrow involvement is more common in indolent disease and can be seen in up to 50% of the cases.

 

About 50% of the patients have extranodal involvement like stomach or gastrointestinal tract (most common primary extranodal site), skin, bones, spinal cord, testicles, among other locations. Renal involvement can be secondary to bulky disease or lymphadenopathy, causing a ureteral obstruction or due to tumor lysis syndrome. DLBCL can also present with symptoms suggestive of superior vena cava syndrome, compression of the airways. The symptoms can be related to the infiltrated organ if the disease spreads beyond the lymphatics in so-called extranodal disease. A variety of paraneoplastic syndromes may also be associated with B cell lymphomas.

 

Metastasis involves the central nervous system (CNS), skin, contralateral testis, and pleura resulting in local complications.

 

Even though ataxia is seen as a paraneoplastic symptom due to cerebellar degeneration in Hodgkin lymphoma, testicular involvement is very rare and so far, only 5 cases have been reported. Hodgkin lymphoma arises in a single node or chain of nodes and spreads first to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. The extranodal presentation is rare. The extranodal disease can occur at any site like lung, liver, bone, and bone marrow is most common if it occurs. The central nervous system and the testis are exceptionally rare sites for Hodgkin's lymphoma. Thus Hodgkin's lymphoma can be ruled out.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glioblastoma multiforme: Most common sites are the frontal and temporal lobes. Extracranial metastases of malignant gliomas are extremely rare due to absence of a lymphatic system in the brain and spinal cord for systemic dissemination, dense dura around intracranial veins and lack of nurturing stroma in other organs.

 

 

Option B. Hodgkin’s Lymphoma: Doesn’t involve the extra nodal sites

 

Option D. Non-seminomatous germ cell tumor: These tumors primarily metastasize to the lungs, liver, CNS, and bone, in order of frequency. Although CNS involvement can occur, it is relatively rare. The combination of scrotal swelling and ataxia is less typical for non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), particularly Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL), is a likely cause of scrotal swelling and ataxia due to its potential for extranodal involvement and associated paraneoplastic syndromes.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the marked area in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stomach

 

The marked area in the image of the left kidney is related to the stomach.

 

 

The diagram shows the anterior relation of kidney:

 

 

The anterior relations of the left kidney involve various structures, including the stomach, spleen, and pancreas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spleen: The spleen is typically located more to the left side of the abdomen, and it is not a direct anterior relation of the left kidney. However, there may be some variability in the position of the spleen, and in some individuals, a small part of the spleen might be located anterior to the left kidney.

 

Option C. 2nd part of duodenum: The second part of the duodenum runs horizontally and is situated anterior to the right kidney, it has no relation to the left kidney. This part of the duodenum is part of the foregut and is involved in the digestion and absorption of nutrients.

 

Option D. Pancreas: Pancreas in general is related to the left kidney but below the level of relation with stomach. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stomach is located anterior to the left kidney. The part of the stomach that lies in close proximity to the left kidney is the lesser curvature, specifically the anterior aspect of the stomach. The left kidney is situated posterior to this portion of the stomach.

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leptospira

 

The life cycle shown in the images is indicative of leptospirosis, a zoonotic disease caused by bacteria of the genus Leptospira. The diagram highlights the transmission cycle involving various animal reservoirs and the environment, which is characteristic of leptospirosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanta virus: Transmitted through aerosolized rodent excreta but does not fit the detailed transmission cycle depicted in the image.

 

Option C. Yersinia pestis: Causes plague, transmitted primarily through fleas, and does not follow the environmental cycle shown in the image.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food and water, and does not have a life cycle involving animal reservoirs as depicted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The life cycle of Leptospira involves transmission from animal reservoirs through contaminated water and soil, leading to human infection, which fits the depiction in the provided images.

questions.text: The slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Loss of myelin sheath

 

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is primarily characterized by the autoimmune-mediated demyelination of central nervous system neurons. The myelin sheath is crucial for proper and fast electrical conduction along nerve fibers; it facilitates saltatory conduction, which allows the action potential to jump rapidly from one node of Ranvier to the next. The loss of this myelin sheath in MS results in significantly slowed and disrupted nerve signal conduction, which underlies many of the neurological symptoms associated with the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gliosis: Gliosis is not seen in MS but seen in viral encephalitis, Alzheimer's disease, traumatic brain injury, and gliomas

 

Option C. Defect at node of Ranvier: Although alterations in the nodes of Ranvier occur secondary to demyelination, the primary issue is the loss of the myelin sheath itself, not initial defects at the nodes.

 

Option D. Leaky Na+ channel: This option refers to a specific type of channelopathy that isn't characteristic of MS. In MS, the problem is more about the insulation (myelin) around the nerve fibers rather than the ion channels within the nerve cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple sclerosis is characterized by demyelination that results in loss of saltatory conduction occurring from one node of Ranvier to the other.

 

Reference - Harrison/Multiple sclerosis/Chap 444

choices.text: Blood volume regulation by the kidney
Temperature control by the hypothalamus
Blood pressure control by baroreceptors

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to the clinic for routine evaluation. During the consultation, the physician discusses various regulatory systems in the body that maintain homeostasis through negative feedback mechanisms. One system is particularly efficient in regulating blood volume by adjusting urine output based on hormonal influences. The physician explains that this system can theoretically achieve a feedback gain approaching infinity, maintaining blood volume within a narrow range. Which of the following systems exhibits a feedback gain of infinity in a negative feedback mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the above

 

The regulation of blood volume by the kidney operates through a highly effective negative feedback mechanism involving hormones like aldosterone and antidiuretic hormone (ADH). When blood volume decreases, the kidneys conserve water and produce concentrated urine to increase blood volume. Conversely, when blood volume is high, the kidneys excrete excess water to reduce blood volume, thereby maintaining fluid balance within a narrow range. Although this process is extremely efficient, it does not truly achieve infinite feedback gain, as biological systems cannot sustain infinite gain without becoming uncontrollable or unstable. The other systems, such as temperature regulation by the hypothalamus and blood pressure control by baroreceptors, also involve negative feedback but are designed to stabilize rather than amplify responses infinitely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood volume regulation by the kidney: This mechanism is exceptionally efficient at maintaining homeostasis but does not achieve true infinite gain. It adjusts fluid balance responsively without reaching uncontrolled extremes, preventing instability.

 

Option B. Temperature control by the hypothalamus: The hypothalamus regulates body temperature through negative feedback mechanisms that involve adjustments in heat production and loss. While effective, this system does not achieve infinite gain and focuses on maintaining thermal stability.

 

Option C. Blood pressure control by baroreceptors: Baroreceptors help regulate blood pressure by adjusting heart rate and vascular resistance through negative feedback. This system effectively prevents large fluctuations but does not involve infinite gain, as that would result in instability.

 

Educational Objective:


Negative feedback mechanisms are critical for maintaining physiological stability, but none achieve true infinite feedback gain. The kidneys' role in blood volume regulation is highly efficient and can theoretically approach infinite gain; however, in reality, biological systems maintain balance within limits to avoid instability.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the OPD with a scald injury on his arm. The lesion was pink, oozing, and painful to moving air and touch. Which of the following would be the most appropriate management? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Collagen dressing

 

Scald injury (damage due to contact with hot liquids) that appears pink in colour, has oozing, and pain is suggestive of a 2nd-degree superficial burn (i.e., partial-thickness burn). Collagen dressing is the most appropriate management for this injury.

 

Collagen dressings are an appropriate choice for partial-thickness burn wounds and scald injuries. They provide several advantages, including promoting wound healing, reducing pain, and helping to maintain a moist environment, which is conducive to tissue repair. Collagen dressings can be especially helpful in managing painful wounds like scald injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silver Sulphadiazine Cream Dressing: Silver sulfadiazine cream is commonly used for burn wounds. However, in the case of a scald injury like the one described (pink, oozing, and painful), silver sulfadiazine cream may not be the first choice. This cream is used for second degree deep and third degree burns.

 

Option B. Excision and Grafting: Excision and grafting are typically reserved for severe burn injuries that involve full-thickness damage to the skin and underlying tissues. In the case of a pink, oozing, and painful scald injury, which is likely partial-thickness, excision and grafting may be overly aggressive and not necessary.

 

Option C. Paraffin Gauze Dressing: Paraffin gauze dressings are often used for burn wounds. They provide a non-adherent surface and help maintain a moist wound environment. While this dressing may be suitable, collagen dressings (Option D) are better at promoting wound healing and tissue repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best dressing for burn wounds is skin; collagen is a good substitute for skin, especially in partial-thickness burns. For full-thickness burns, sequential excision and grafting must be considered.

 

Initial treatment for burns includes cleaning the burnt areas and removing loose dead skin. Blisters are de-roofed and an appropriate dressing is applied.

 

Biological dressing (collagen dressings, amniotic membrane, etc.) is the preferred dressing material, especially in partial thickness burns.

 

If this is not available then a non-adhesive dressing like paraffin gauze impregnated with silver sulfadiazine (SSD) cream, colloidal silver, ionic silver cream, or silver nitrate cream may be applied. Since increased resistance to SSD has recently emerged, it should be used judiciously and reserved for deep dermal, full thickness, infected, and old neglected burns.

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CSF PCR for viral DNA

 

 

HS-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis.

 

Other investigations that can help include:

 

  • CSF examination
  • CSF culture
  • Serological studies
  • MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

 

The image shows coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes in a patient with HSV encephalitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgM antibodies in CSF: Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

 

Option B. Tzanck smear of CSF: Rapid, fairly sensitive and inexpensive diagnostic method, but prepared from the lesions, preferably from the base of vesicles and stained with 1% aqueous solution of toluidine blue ‘0’ for 15 seconds, not CSF.

 

Option D. CSF culture in chick embryos: HSV-1 doesn’t grow well on Chick embryo line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid and accurate diagnosis of HSV encephalitis, CSF PCR for viral DNA is the gold standard, essential for guiding appropriate antiviral therapy.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a serious complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. The diagnostic criteria for DKA typically include:

 

  • Hyperglycemia: Blood glucose levels greater than 250 mg/dL.
  • Ketosis: Presence of ketones in the blood or urine.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: Indicated by an arterial pH of less than 7.3, a serum bicarbonate level of less than 15-18 mEq/L, and an anion gap greater than 12.

 

S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L is not a diagnostic criterion for DKA. Although potassium imbalance is common in DKA due to shifts between the intracellular and extracellular compartments, serum potassium levels are not used as a diagnostic criterion. Potassium levels can vary and might be normal, elevated, or decreased, depending on the stage of DKA and the treatment administered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S. glucose > 250 mg/dL: This is a diagnostic criterion for DKA as it confirms the presence of significant hyperglycemia.

 

Option B. Arterial pH < 7.3: This indicates metabolic acidosis, which is a key component of DKA.

 

Option C. Anion gap > 12: An increased anion gap signifies high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), which is typical in DKA due to the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for DKA include hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Potassium levels, while important to monitor and manage in DKA, are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: On thyroid function test analysis, TSH value was much higher than normal with low free T4. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Primary hypothyroidism

 

HYPOTHYROIDISM

 

Types:

 

  1. Primary Hypothyroidism - Increased TSH with low T4 levels.
  2. Secondary hypothyroidism - TSH can be low, normal or elevated slightly. The latter is due to secretion of immune-active but bio-active forms of TSH. Confirmation of diagnosis is done by detecting low levels of unbound T4.

 

Evaluation of Hypothyroidism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical hypothyroidism: Incorrect because subclinical hypothyroidism would show an elevated TSH but normal free T4 levels.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: Incorrect as hyperthyroidism would typically present with low TSH and high free T4 levels.

 

Option C. Secondary hypothyroidism: Incorrect for this scenario because secondary hypothyroidism involves a problem with pituitary TSH production, which does not typically result in a significantly elevated TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary hypothyroidism is characterized by high TSH and low free T4 levels, indicating a failure of the thyroid gland itself to produce sufficient hormones.

1400 for mother and 600 for ASHA
